California Guide

ADU law changes in 2026: what to check before you file.

State ADU rules keep narrowing local discretion, but city-level objective standards still matter. This page focuses on the checks that reduce correction cycles.

Last updated: 2026-02-18

Get Permit Dossier ($499) Call/Text

Fast filing checklist

  • Confirm your jurisdiction and review workflow before drawing final sets.
  • Map objective standards: setbacks, height, access, egress, and open-space constraints.
  • Separate ADU scope from unrelated remodel work when it prevents extra plan check comments.
  • Document utility assumptions early (electrical panel size, sewer, water meter impact).
  • Use permit history to avoid repeating old correction triggers at the same address.

Where teams lose time

  • Submitting generic statewide assumptions without city-specific objective standards.
  • Missing plan notes that reviewers expect on first pass.
  • Bundling too many scopes into one permit set.
  • Underestimating correction turnarounds around holidays or staffing gaps.

For Los Angeles-specific sequencing, use the LA ADU permit process guide.

FAQ

Do 2026 ADU changes remove all local design rules?

No. Cities still apply objective standards, but those standards cannot conflict with state ADU limits.

Can my city require owner occupancy for every ADU permit?

Many owner-occupancy mandates are limited or constrained by state law. Verify the exact local rule version before filing.

Are replacement parking spaces still required after garage conversion?

Often no, but this depends on project type and local interpretation. Confirm on your pre-check call.

How long should ADU permit review take in practice?

Target statutory timelines may be short, but real cycle time depends on completeness, correction rounds, and department load.

Should I file ADU and main-house scope together?

Usually split scopes when feasible. Combined scopes often trigger broader plan check comments and slow issuance.

What is the fastest way to avoid first-round corrections?

Use a city-specific checklist and confirm objective standards before finalizing drawings, especially setbacks, access, and utility notes.
